awd_abstract_narration: The "Inquiry Hub" project brings together a partnership of educational researchers, computer scientists, school district leaders, curriculum developers, interactive resource providers, and multiple publishers of STEM curricula to undertake a systemic approach to learner-centered teaching that promotes adaptability and responsiveness to the differing needs of diverse learners. The partnership integrates several prominent technology and curriculum innovations resulting from prior NSF support, which are being deployed in iterative cycles of user-driven, design-based implementation research. Formative data such as usage logs, surveys, interviews, and classroom observations are informing successive versions of this work; and a longitudinal analysis utilizing hierarchical linear modeling is being used to evaluate impact on teacher practice and student learning. The project has three primary outputs: i) a content platform to make rigorous, learner-centered curriculum resources more widely accessible to students, teachers, and districts; ii) innovative software adaptation services, coupled with targeted professional development, to significantly improve teachers' ability to customize their teaching with learner-centered curricula so as to better meet the needs of diverse learners; and iii) a network of partner organizations and businesses to provide the social platform necessary for scaling and sustaining the project's activities. The intellectual merit of this project lies in its demonstration of a model for employing digital curricula and cyberlearning services to bring about improvements to teaching and learning at scale. In particular, it is advancing theory and practical knowledge in three areas: i) the state- of-the-art in computational infrastructures to support an efficient way to offer customized views of content, ii) learning science theory to study how innovative cyberlearning services enable teachers to make effective adaptations to learning resources so as to meet the needs of diverse learners, and iii) understanding of the social structures and collaboration processes needed to scale and sustain research-based, cyberlearning innovations that involve multiple institutional actors. The project's broader impacts are being felt through its development of a new organizational and business model for bringing research-based, digital curriculum and software services to market. Furthermore, testing the implementation of this project in a large, diverse urban district is demonstrating its viability as a cost-effective mechanism for bringing learner-centered teaching and curriculum to scale in a way that leads to improved learning for all.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
iHub Project Outcomes Report

 

The iHub project produced rigorous, learner-centered science and math curriculum materials that are accessible to students, teachers, and districts via an online repository and instructional planning tool (the Curriculum Customization Service). These materials were developed as part of a research-practice partnership in the collaborating school district focused on the co-design of innovative, digital STEM curriculum. The collaborating school district serves an urban student population in which the majority come from non-dominant backgrounds (>77%) and quality for free or reduced lunch (>68%). Teachers, district leaders, university researchers, and scientists from partner organizations worked together to prototype, pilot, and then revise the curriculum materials based on a wide array of data analyses and structured feedback.

 

The math curriculum developed by the iHub project includes 55 high-quality algebraic tasks and 7 instructional playlists illustrating how to implement and adapt rigorous tasks to promote equity with diverse learners. These tasks support the implementation of the Common Core State Standards and enable secondary students to access high levels of mathematics content without lowering the cognitive demand. Pilot studies indicate that the tasks help students (including English learners) participate in and comprehend mathematically productive discussions in their classes.

 

To skillfully adapt the tasks for their own classrooms, teachers benefitted from specific scaffolds related to implementing high-quality tasks, in particular to support their launch and discussion of the mathematics. These scaffolds provide important supports for English learners and enable teachers to anticipate how to ensure all students have access to learning from high-quality tasks.

 

The science curriculum developed by the iHub project includes two high school biology units - ecosystems and evolution – that were co-designed by teachers, district leaders, university researchers, and scientists from partner organizations. The units reflect the vision of the Framework for K-12 Science Education, integrating disciplinary core ideas, science and engineering practices, and cross-cutting concepts. The units incorporate open educational resources as well as customized online applications, and are designed to support equitable engagement of diverse learners. Sustained professional development was provided to all teachers who used the curriculum, including teachers who did and did not take part in their co-design.

 

A wealth of data was collected throughout the development and implementation process including teacher interviews, classroom observations, student surveys, and assessments. These data suggest the biology units promote forms of classroom activity that align with the Next Generation Science Standards, foster citizen science and technology use, and support positive student learning outcomes. Teachers who participated in the co-design process demonstrated growth in their understanding of three dimensional science learning, and leveraged this understanding as they helped to create lessons. Student-centered measures indicate the curriculum enhanced their sense of agency, and they found the anchoring phenomenon in the units to be exciting and engaging; however, there was a large degree of variation in instructional coherence across teachers who implemented the units.

 

The iHub project was committed to meeting the goals of multiple stakeholders including: district leader, teacher and student learning; furthering research on the effective conduct of research-practice partnerships to create digital STEM curriculum; and developing curricular materials that can be widely distributed. The project achieved these goals by creating math and science curricular materials that have been used by over 1000 students, positively impacting both teacher and student learning, and supporting sustainable and distributed learning at the district administration level.  Moreover, analyses from the collaborative partnership offer insights into how to organize effective research and curriculum development efforts that include district and school-level stakeholders in extended and meaningful design work. Lastly, the project has directly contributed to the public use of its cyberlearning tools by making the Curriculum Customization Service available to districts in three states and teachers nationwide.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/26/2016
Modified by: Tamara R Sumner
